ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LEGAL AID AND ADVICE ORDINANCE
(Extension of provisions to cover criminal matters before High Court)


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether he will consider extending the provisions of the Legal Aid and Advice Ordinance to criminal matters before the High Court, and what is the estimated cost of such extension.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the view of the Government is that the present structure of the legal aid system in Singapore is not suitable for extension to criminal cases.

    The legal aid system in England as administered by the Law Society is not concerned with criminal legal aid. The system of criminal legal aid in England is administered through the Courts themselves. The Chairman of Quarter Sessions himself considers all applications for legal aid in his court and grants or rejects applications in his sole discretion. Likewise do the Magistrates. So also does the Judge or Commissioner in the Old Bailey.

    If a legal aid scheme for criminal cases is introduced, it must, if it is to be fairly administered, apply to all cases whether before the High Court or before the subordinate Courts. This is the practice in England. There is already in existence a scheme whereby lawyers are assigned to accused persons charged with capital offences. All provisions in the Legal Aid and Advice Ordinance envisage recourse to the English system. This would mean the Courts administering criminal legal aid, considering all such applications and assigning all cases which they think should be granted legal aid to members of the profession. The

Column: 104

profession therefore would have to play an even more active role in participating in such a legal aid scheme if legal aid is to be extended to criminal cases. Such an extension of the legal aid system must apply to all criminal cases, not only the High Court cases, and the members of the profession must be prepared to participate on the basis that no assigned brief can be refused at the rates to be prescribed even though members of the profession can command higher fees on other work in respect of the time employed on such assigned cases.

    The Government would prefer legal aid to be given in criminal cases by the Bench with the full co-operation of the Bar as it is the practice in England, rather than legal aid to be provided by lawyers in full-time Government employment. It does seem odd that the State should prosecute offenders and, at the same time, engage lawyers in full-time employment to defend these offenders. I know this is the practice in certain States in Australia, but we have been used to the practice here of assigning counsel for the defence in capital charges, and this system could very well be extended by adopting the English practice in regard to the grant of legal aid in criminal cases.

    One great advantage of the English system of legal aid in criminal cases, which is completely outside the English legal aid service operated by the Law Society in civil cases, is that it is operated by the Judiciary and the Bar. Judges can be depended on to look fairly into the legal points of criminal cases which are before them for trial and can be depended on to reject applications for legal aid in criminal cases where no points of legal difficulty are likely to arise. It is not the intention of the scheme of legal aid in criminal cases in England or here to grant legal aid to all and sundry but to grant it in criminal cases involving fine points of the law.

    It is not possible to estimate accurately the cost of extending the legal aid scheme to all criminal matters before the High Court. There were 152 criminal cases tried in the High Court in 1961

Column: 105

and 1962, and if the costs per case are estimated at $1,000, the cost to Government of extending legal aid to all criminal cases in the High Court will be around $76,000 a year.

    As the administration of justice will be a Federal matter, estimates for such a scheme will have to be approved by the Central Government, and the Singapore Government is in no position to accept any such commitment on its own responsibility.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): Is the Minister aware that the Bar Committee fully support the suggestion of the extension of free legal aid to all criminal cases in the High Court, whether the appellate or original jurisdiction? If he is, would he consider negotiating with them with a view to evolving a scheme satisfactory to that end?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have already explained, the administration of justice is a Federal responsibility. We cannot as a Government enter into any commitments on our own responsibility.

    If the Bar Committee had been really keen on the extension of legal aid to criminal cases, they would have taken steps to see that such a system was introduced. But so far, they have only voiced the opinion that the legal aid system is acceptable to them. But they have done nothing to further their demand for the extension of legal aid.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Does the Minister not consider that the provision of legal and is a social amenity and not in the course of the administration of justice?

    Mr Byrne: You have to run the legal aid system in a proper way. I have just pointed out to Members of the House that in England it is administered by the Bar in co-operation with the Judiciary.

    It is not the intention to give legal aid to everybody who makes a claim for legal aid in criminal cases. It is only granted in cases where there are points of law involved and it is only the Judge who can decide what case is fit and proper for the grant of legal aid.

Column: 106



    Mr David Marshall: I will not take much of the time of the Minister. I have just one more question to ask. Is he not conscious that throughout Australia and the United States free legal aid is granted in all criminal cases? I am sure he is conscious that in Singapore, where the vast majority of our population do not speak the language of the administration of justice, it is particularly important that they should have legal assistance not merely where points of law arise but for the proper presentation of their cases. In these circumstances, would he reconsider the position?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have said all that needs to be said on this matter. If the Bar Committee in Singapore really want the extension of legal aid to criminal matters, it is up to them to press this demand more vigorously than they have done in the past.

UNIVERSITY OF SINGAPORE
(Number of students and Government grants in 1962/63)


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Education to state (a) the number of students studying in the University of Singapore in (i) 1962, and (ii) 1963; (b) the amount of the Government grants to the University in 1962/63; and (c) the basis on which such grants are made.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: The number of students studying in the University of Singapore in 1962 was 2,149 and in 1963 is 2,431.

    The amount of Government grants to the University in 1962 was $8.5 million of which $400,000 was subject to Treasury sanction. For 1963, which was passed by the Legislative Assembly on the 14th of last month, the sum voted was $8,754,550 of which $254,550 is subject to Treasury sanction.

    Grants are made on the basis of estimates of income and expenditure of the University submitted by the University authorities to the Government for its consideration. On the basis of past experience, the Government then decides on the annual grant to be made to the University.

Column: 107



    Mr David Marshall: From the figures indicated by the Minister, there seems to be a 14 per cent increase in enrolment but not a proportionate increase in grant, is the Minister satisfied that the grant is adequate for the needs of the University for the year in question?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I should like to say to the Member for Anson that it is not quite necessary for the annual grant to the University to be kept in proportion to the number of students. In fact, as the number of students increases, the cost to tile University per student should decrease. I will say this, that for 1962, on an estimated student enrolment of 2,120, the University requested a grant of $9.91 million. Of this, $680,000 was to be for research and post-graduate education. Although the Government grant was $1.4 million short of the University's expectation, it is reliably understood that despite an increased enrolment of 2,149 instead of 2,120 as estimated by the University, there will still be a surplus.

WORK BRIGADE
(Setting up of Commission)


    3. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for National Development whether he will consider setting up a Commission to inquire into the functioning of the Work Brigade and to make recommendation for its future.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, the Work Brigade was set up in March 1960 with the following objects:

    Firstly, to keep in useful and gainful occupation youths between the ages of 16 and 30 who would otherwise he swelling the ranks of the unemployed.

    Secondly, to place them in permanent employment in Government and other organisations in the State after a period of training designed to turn them into useful citizens.

    Through the years since March 1960, thousands of youths have been kept in useful and gainful occupation and over 2,000 youths have found employment through the Work Brigade.

Column: 108



    Sir, the Singapore Work Brigade has been functioning satisfactorily and I see no reason for setting up a Commission to inquire into the functioning of the Work Brigade.

    Mr David Marshall: May I ask the Minister whether he is not aware that it is generally believed that the Work Brigade is being used for political demonstrations and some of the members are being coerced thereto and paid public monies therefor? And would he not consider it helpful in the public interest that these rumours - whether true or untrue - should be nailed down by a public inquiry which would also assist in considering the future of these people?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: I can imagine all sorts of rumours about the Work Brigade because the election for the 15 seats to the Federal Parliament is drawing very near. Rumours will fly round anyway. For the Member's information, other than doing the routine work of the Work Brigade, Work Brigade members do crowd control work. For instance, on National Day or during Singapore Air Show Day or during the Singapore or Malaysian Grand Prix, Work Brigade members are used to prepare the site, to help in crowd control and many other things. These are the duties which the Work Brigade have performed to our satisfaction and we are satisfied with the functioning of the Work Brigade. As I have said, there is no necessity to set up this Commission of Inquiry.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister for National Development aware that members of the Work Brigade have been selling P.A.P. party organs during their working hours? I would like to ask him whether he intends to set up a Commission to inquire into this matter and to see that members of the Work Brigade should be employed in their proper functions and not do something else for the benefit of the Party in power.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, during the days when the Member for Choa Chu Kang and the Member for Toa Payoh were with us on this side of the Assembly, I also heard that they were using Work Brigade members for their own purpose.

Column: 109

At that time, of course, it was for P.A.P. purpose, and there was no necessity for a Commission of Inquiry because these were mere rumours. If the Member for Choa Chu Kang can substantiate what he has said just now, I will set up a Commission of Inquiry.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, after having run the Work Brigade for nearly three years, would the Government not consider that a Commission of Inquiry would be able to inquire whether the present $1.50 per day allowance is sufficient for their purpose and whether we should increase it to $3 per day?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, the idea of admitting unemployed youths into the Work Brigade is to give them a period of training and find proper employment for them outside the Work Brigade. We do not intend to keep them in the Work Brigade forever. The allowance of $1.50 a day is to tide them over their weekend, the days when they are free to go out and enjoy a bit. This sum of $1.50 is not intended as a salary for them.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, a little while ago the Minister for National Development said that if I could produce the evidence, then he would consider setting up a Commission of Inquiry. Now I ask the Minister to set it up to look into the whole task of the Work Brigade and then we will get evidence as to -

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member is now entering into a debate. He has been asked to substantiate what he has to say, and if he can do so, then the Minister has undertaken to make an inquiry. That is the end of it. He must not enter into a debate now. Is it a question, he wishes to ask?

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, my question is very simple. If the Minister would like to set up a Commission of Inquiry, then we would be prepared to give evidence to this Commission.

    Mr Speaker: That is not a question.

Column: 110



    Mr David Marshall: Would the Minister indicate what is the average period that a member of the Work Brigade remains in the organisation, if he is in possession of that information at the moment?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: The maximum period is nine months.

SINGAPORE (ELECTIONS TO THE FEDERAL HOUSE OF

REPRESENTATIVES) BILL



    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [24th July, 1963], "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Question again proposed.

2.50 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, when the House adjourned yesterday, I was touching on the arrogant attitude of the Member for Cairnhill, who claimed to be the representative of the Alliance which opposed the Bill now under discussion. In passing, I also replied to his charges that the object of this Bill was to ensure safe seats for P.A.P. Ministers and strong men in the P.A.P. In point of fact, as I said yesterday, the Member for Cairnhill did practise this tactic for his own benefit, and now he is throwing the same charges at others. I know how efficient the Member for Cairnhill is in protecting himself or in saving himself from extinction. In the first election when he contested the Keppel Ward, he stood in the name of the Labour Party. In 1955 he contested in the name of the Labour Front, and in 1959 again on the S.P.A. ticket, and maybe the next year in the name of the Alliance. He reminds me of the proverbial hermit-crab, whose anterior is similar to that of a crab but whose posterior is that of a snail. The body of this hermit-crab is weak. This hermit-crab has no shell for its lodging. He has only another's shell to ensure his safety. Now it is clear that the lodging where this hermit-crab is sheltering will not be safe for the creature. This is the type of tactic that will be employed by people like Members who are afraid

Column: 111

of being defeated in elections; leaving the Labour Party and later on the Labour Front and S.P.A. Now he makes the charge against the Government that this Bill is designed to ensure safe seats for P.A.P. Ministers. The Prime Minister will not run away from Tanjong Pagar; likewise each and every Member of the P.A.P. will return to his constituency to face the people. We are prepared to face the people at the appropriate time.

    Mr Speaker, we saw the behaviour of the Member for Cairnhill yesterday when he heat his chest as though to claim that only the Alliance represents the people of Singapore. But he forgets that the Alliance Headquarters is in Kuala Lumpur. In spite of all his boast, the Alliance has not been able to find a suitable Chairman from one of its colleagues in Singapore. They have to run to Kuala Lumpur to find the Chairman. If -

    Mr Speaker: Order. May I remind the Hon. Parliamentary Secretary that we are not debating the Alliance'? He is in order up till now. He has attacked the Member for Cairnhill. That is in order. When he goes further and starts debating about the Alliance, and who the Chairman of the Alliance is, I think he is going a hit too far, and going further and further away from the Bill itself.

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj(In Malay): Mr Speaker, we know that the object of this Bill is to provide for the election of 15 representatives to the Federal House of Representatives. But the Member for Cairnhill is so scared to face the people that in his speech yesterday he said that the 15 elected Members should be nominated from among the 51 Assemblymen in Singapore. This is clear proof that he wants to save himself. The 15 representatives must be elected by the people. Where then is the logic that we must nominate them - not elected by the people to represent them - to the Federal House of Representatives?

    Mr Speaker, the Member for Cairnhill also said that the forthcoming Federal elections, if this Bill is passed, mean nothing more than a waste of public

Column: 112

funds. Every five years there is this opportunity for the people to pass judgment on their elected representatives whether in the Legislative Assembly or in the future Federal House of Representatives. We must give this opportunity to the people to choose their representatives. Does he consider that such expenses are a misuse of public funds, if they claim to be champions of democracy'? Now we are going to expend money to enable the people to elect their representatives. He considers this a waste of money! I do not see the logic, Mr Speaker.

    Mr Speaker, although you have pulled me up just now, I should like to say a little more. The real motive behind the Member for Cairnhill's opposition to this Bill is I his, and it is a coincidence that this appeared in today's Utusan Melayu in an article headed "Federal House of Representatives Elections". It says that the UMNO-MCA-MIC will each get four seats, and the balance will be for the S.P.A. Because the S.P.A. get a less number of seats, they have shown opposition and they are not prepared to contest the elections. It may be that when the elections take place, we might see a lot of S.P.A. and Independent candidates contesting.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether the Hon. Parliamentary Secretary can tell us where he got that information from.

    Inche Yaacob continued speaking in Malay.

    Mr Speaker: Order, I suppose the answer is "from the newspaper". Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary will tell us which newspaper and of which date.

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I did say I was quoting from today's Utusan Melayu under the heading "Federal Elections - UMNO-MCA-MIC each to get 4 seats." This means that the S.P.A. will get three seats. This is what they fear. This will result in many Independent candidates from the S.P.A. contesting against their own Singapore Alliance candidates, as happened in the previous City Council and Legislative Assembly elections when

Column: 113

they fought against UMNO candidates in the constituencies.

    The reason why the Member for Cairnhill strongly opposes this Bill is due to party interests.

    Yesterday a representative of the Barisan Sosialis sang the same old song; the same gramophone record. There were nothing but the oft-repeated terms, "dictatorship", "undemocratic", and, at the same time, they accused the Government of adopting an attitude that is nothing short of dictatorship. We are going to face the people now. Because Singapore held its first referendum, she was able to solve the merger problem. Now where is her self-respect if we cannot send elected representatives to the Federal Parliament? If the Opposition Members claim to have the support of the people, then they should have no fear. Let them go back to the people and let the people judge. That is democracy. We pass this Bill and we then face the people. We do not want to see Singapore sending nominated representatives to the Federal Parliament.

    Yesterday the Member for Punggol, in prefacing his speech, apologised and said that his speech should have been delivered by his Party leader, the Member for Hong Lim, who was then indisposed. I sympathise with the Member for Hong Lim. My friend informed me yesterday that a Chinese newspaper reported that committee members of the U.P.P. Branch in Havelock had resigned en bloc. I feel very sorry for the Member for Hong Lim. The Member for Punggol said yesterday that this Bill deprives the right of the Assembly, because all election Bills must be approved by the Assembly. We are now debating this election Bill and this Assembly will have to approve this Bill to make it law in order to enable us to face the people in the elections. There is no meaning in shouting out that the people are behind them when, in asking the Opposition to approve this Bill, they turn around and charge us by saying that the Bill is dictatorial, undemocratic and so on.

    Mr Speaker, on the delineation of the constituencies, Members opposite have said that there should be an All-Party

Column: 114

conference. My colleague, the Deputy Prime Minister, emphasised yesterday that the door is still open. We are prepared to meet the Opposition on an equal basis, i.e. four to four. If they really represent the people of Singapore, there is nothing for them to be afraid of about the boundaries of the constituency. We must be prepared to stand in any constituency, whether it be Bukit Timah or Tanjong Pagar, if we are sure of the support of the masses. This is only their manoeuvre to cover up their faults and weaknesses.

    Briefly, Mr Speaker, this Bill provides for the election of 15 representatives from Singapore to sit in the Federal Parliament, and not of representatives to be nominated by this Assembly.

3.09 p.m.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore (Elections to the Federal House of Representatives) Bill is a real menace to the democratic system. It is a shame of the P.A.P. Government, and provides a fitting concluding chapter to the P.A.P. reign of four years which, in the beginning, came in like a crest of wave but is reduced to nothing, like the foam which we see after the wave has rolled out into the ocean.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this sitting is the most vital in the history of this Assembly in the past four years. As far as the P.A.P.'s fate is concerned, this Bill is the most vital one. To the P.A.P. it outweighs in importance the debates on the Malaysia Agreement and other motions. It will provide the Minister with all the powers necessary to run the coming Parliamentary election of 15 seats as he likes. The rule of law has given way to the rule of decree. Just remember the days of the Japanese occupation when whatever the Japanese Kempeitai said either by imperial edict or by decree, had the force of law. Even a chop by a Kempeitai officer on a piece of scrap paper could mean life or death to thousands of people. Although we have not approached that state, we are seeing the beginnings of such a state. In the past few months we

Column: 115

have seen more and more the Government's intention to introduce government by decree, government by edict, instead of government by consent, government by rule of law. So why does the P.A.P. not abolish this Legislature and, at the same time, appoint a Japanese type of judiciary so that tyranny can be more complete?

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Yes, we will appoint you.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, in that case the first person I will fix up is the Deputy Prime Minister.

    Perhaps it is not that the P.A.P. Government lacks the intent or the will hut the powers behind the scenes could see the catastrophe if the present cat-and-mouse type of democracy is further allowed to deteriorate. As I myself see it, the Bill has three purposes. Its primary purpose is to avoid Federal elections for Singapore's 15 representatives being conducted not under the more independent Federation Elections Commission but under P.A.P. control. We can expect and envisage what the course of these elections would be like, particularly after our experience in the National Referendum campaign. The P.A.P. hopes that by rigging the elections it can win a few seats, and if these elections could be held before 31st August they would then still have control over the Police machinery - the Special Branch and the C.I.D. - which would be useful weapons in rigging the elections. Further, with all this paraphernalia of State control, the P.A.P. can hope to win a few seats which will provide a prop in the coming State elections.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, months ago in our Party paper we have already analysed what these elections would be like. We have already foreseen that there would be elections before 31st August if the P.A.P. Government had its way. We have already foreseen as far hack as May this year that there would be an undemocratic delineation of boundaries. I already have a draft list of what the P.A.P. proposes to do with the boundaries. As stated in our Party organ,

Column: 116

we have already foreseen that one of the purposes was to seek safe seats for the P.A.P. Ministers. Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Health and Law will not have a safe seat at all because he is now not in the good hooks of the Prime Minister.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if the P.A.P. can win a few seats, then we can expect the coming State elections to be held very soon; it might be after a few weeks. But if the P.A.P. faces complete calamity, then we can expect the P.A.P. Prime Minister running again after the British and asking them to provide more time so that he can find further ways and means to save the P.A.P. from complete disaster.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the second purpose of this Bill is to provide for special counting - and this we foresaw long ago - so that the results of the 51 State constituencies, although regrouped into 15 for Federal constituencies, could be known only to the P.A.P. Mr Speaker, this is the way it will be done. Suppose Geylang West, Geylang East, Mountbatten and Joo Chiat were regrouped into one Federal constituency; during the counting there would be four tables and the tour Presiding Officers would know the actual number of P.A.P. votes for each State division. But the Opposition candidates and their counting agents could only know the total number of votes cast for each of the Parties. In other words, the P.A.P. would have the additional advantage of knowing their exact strength in each of the 51 State constituencies. Let us assume that out of the 51 constituencies, the P.A.P. can pick up five or six. Kreta Ayer is supposed to be their strongest constituency. They want to know exactly how the people there vote. Tanjong Pagar, they want to know how the people there vote. Anson, with the Work Brigade, they want to know how the people there vote. Now, these five or six safe seats would be allotted to the most trusted Ministers of the P.A.P. And as I have said just now, the Minister for Health and Law is not one of the trusted Ministers -

Column: 117



    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): He seems to be a prophet, Sir.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: The P.A.P. Ministers will hope, therefore, by such an operation to pick out the safe seats, if any is left, and leave the P.A.P. Back-benchers to swim on their own.

    The third purpose of this Bill, as I see it, is to see that the Prime Minister himself is elected to the Malaysian Parliament. This - we knew it for the first time yesterday - is for a period of six years. We were given the impression that it would be for a period of nine months. But it is for a period of six years. So that he, having failed to deceive the people of Singapore and us here, could be able to manipulate and play his political pranks with the Members of Parliament from the Sabah territories, from Sarawak and from the Federation, both on the Opposition and the Government benches. Mr Speaker, Sir, it is quite a wild venture, but if he gets in, I can assure you that he can do a lot of pranks. Sir, everything is being done to see that the Prime Minister is one of the 15 to go in. Whether any other P.A.P. Minister gets in or not, whether any of the other 14 is P.A.P. or non-P.A.P. actually is not so important as the Prime Minister himself getting in. Because if the Prime Minister can get into the Federation Parliament, he will be able to convince Donald Stephens and then the Sarawak delegation's all totalling 40 votes; he will try to get the Opposition benches in the Federation Parliament, because, Mr Speaker, Sir, nobody in the Malaysian Parliament can beat, as we must acknowledge, his powers of oratory. Those who admire him say his powers of oratory; those who do not admire him say his powers to twist and turn. But he will be able to convince the Sabah M.P.s. the Sarawak M.P.s. the Opposition M.P.s and even the Alliance Back benchers. Mr Speaker, Sir, the Federal Parliament will be like a cauldron where water would be boiling. Everything is now being done in Singapore to see that our great Prime

Column: 118

Minister goes into the Malaysian Parliament. Last week, a $2 million so-called Malaysian bonus - it is not a Malaysian bonus, it is the Prime Minister's Federation M.P. bonus at our expense - was given to the workers and they have been waiting for four years.
